Graphical abstract Description In this review, the catalytic mechanism of electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) and several factors affecting NRR catalysts are summarized, and several opportunities in this field are presented. The nitrogen cycle plays an important role in nature, but N-containing products cannot meet human needs. The electrochemical synthesis of ammonia under ambient conditions has attracted the interest of many researchers because it provides a clean and pollution-free synthesis method; however, it has certain difficulties, including a high activation energy, multiple electron transfer, and hydrogenation. Thermodynamic factors limit the selectivity and activity of ammonia synthesis techniques. This review summarizes progress in the electrochemical synthesis of ammonia from theory and experiment. Theoretically, the reduction of nitrogen molecules is analyzed using orbit theory and the thermodynamic reaction pathways. Experimentally, we first discuss the effect of the experimental setup on the nitrogen reduction reaction, and then the four critical of catalysts, including size, electronic, coordination, and orientation effects. These issues must be considered to produce highly-efficient catalysts for electrochemical nitrogen reduction (eNRR). This review provides an overview of the eNRR to enable future researchers to design rational catalysts. Keywords Nitrogen reduction reaction NRR Electrocatalyst Nitrogen-fixing 1 Introduction Ammonia (NH3) is not only important to energy storage intermediates and carbon-free energy carriers, but it is also necessary for the production of fertilizers, amino acids, and proteins. Almost all nitrogen-containing chemicals are downstream products, such as nitric acid, agricultural nitrogen fertilizer, trinitrotoluene, nitroglycerin, and synthetic fibers [1,2]. Global NH3 production is currently about 200 million tons per year, and the growing demands of the world's population are ever increasing [3–5]. Nitrogen fixation is a key step in the earth's nitrogen cycle, second only to photosynthesis in biological cycles. Current nitrogen fixation methods include lightning nitrogen fixation, biological nitrogen fixation, industrial nitrogen fixation, photocatalytic nitrogen fixation, and electrocatalytic nitrogen fixation [6–10]. Lightning nitrogen fixation and biological nitrogen fixation are both natural nitrogen fixation methods. Lightning nitrogen fixation refers to the instantaneous temperature (up to 30,000 K) during a lightning strike, whereby an increase in the local air pressure, dissociates N2 and O2 molecules to generate atomic free radicals [11,12]. These free radicals combine to form stable molecules such as nitric oxide (NO), nitrogen dioxide (NO2), O3, O2, and N2 after a lightning discharge. The nitrogen oxides formed through this process can further react with atmospheric water to generate nitric acid, which acts as a fertilizer when it reaches the earth’s surface. For example, nitrate ions in water can be reduced by humus to nitrite, N2, and NH4 + ions. Another gentler nitrogen fixation in nature is biological nitrogen fixation method in nature is biological nitrogen fixation, whereby certain microorganisms, including bacteria and archaea, use nitrogenase to reduce nitrogen to NH3 at room temperature. Nitrogenase is a two-component system composed of Fe protein and MoFe protein [13], in which Fe proteolytically hydrolyzes adenosine triphosphate (ATP). The energy released is used to transfer electrons to the MoFe protein, which is the active site where N2 is reduced to NH3. Only some symbiotic bacteria (mainly those that are symbiotic with legumes) and some non-symbiotic bacteria can fix nitrogen and absorb it in the form of organic nitrogen. The industrialization of modern ammonia synthesis technology began in 1905. The German chemist Haber confirmed after a large number of experiments that hydrogen and nitrogen achieved ammonia synthesis for the first time under the conditions of catalyst and high temperature (500–600 °C) and high pressure (17.5–20 MPa) (Eq. (1)) [14]. At present, the traditional Haber-Bosch method is extensively used in the industry. This method requires a pressure of 150–350 atm, a temperature of 350–550 °C, consumes 1–2% of total global energy annually, and releases ~1.5% of total greenhouse gas emissions. Thus, ammonia synthesis is still highly energy-intensive, making it incredibly important to develop ammonia synthesis routes with milder conditions. (1) N 2 + 2 H 2 ⇌ 2 N H 3 In the past decade, a series of new nitrogen fixation strategies have emerged, including enzymatic catalysis, photocatalysis, and electrocatalysis. These reactions allow NH3 to be synthesized at room temperature, but the synthesis rate is much lower than industrial reactions [1,15,16]. Although their inherent advantages/disadvantages and their practical applicability to large-scale nitrogen fixation have not been fully discussed, tremendous progress has been made in understanding their mechanism and performance. This review summarizes the current status of electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction, including a theoretical understanding and experimental progress. Experimental progress is divided into a summary of the setting and influence of the catalyst, including size, electronic, coordination, and orientation effects (Fig. 1 ). We then summarize current problems and provide guidance for future developments. 2 The nitrogen reduction reaction mechanism To enhance the efficiency of the nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR), it is essential to understand its reaction mechanism. The high triple bond energy (941 kJ mol−1), makes N2 chemically inert, and a proper catalyst is needed to lower the activation energy [17]. The first step in the overall reaction mechanism is the adsorption and activation of nitrogen molecules on the catalyst surface, but this step is difficult to because N2 molecules are non-polar and highly stable molecules. Besides, nitrogen molecules have a large energy gap (10.82 eV) between the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) (Fig. 2 ). Nitrogen molecules have a high ionization energy (15.58 eV) and low electron affinity (−1.9 eV) [18–21], which make nitrogen chemically inert under normal conditions, therefore, the rational design of active sites on a catalyst is very important. An ideal NRR catalyst should have a strong activation (i.e. low activation energy, E a) for N2, but should only weakly bind (i.e. low adsorption energy, ΔE) to intermediate species [22]. NRR involves multiple proton-electron transfer reactions and different intermediate products, and these intermediate products have a proportional relationship. Since the N2 reduction product NH3 forms NH4 + in an aqueous solution, which is affected by the pH. And the NRR may involve six-electron, four-electron, and two-electron pathways depending upon the pH (Eqs. (2)–(5)) [15]. The form of ammonia in an aqueous solution depends entirely on the pH of the solution. When pH ≥ 9.25, ammonia is present in the molecular form of NH3, and when pH < 9.25, it mainly exists as NH4 + ions. Hydrazine may be a by-product in the nitrogen reduction products. Hydrazine is also similar and when pH ≥ 6.07, it exists as a neutral molecule, N2H4, and when pH < 6.07, it exists as N2H5 + [23,24]. The first step of nitrogen reduction is the transfer of an electron from the catalyst to an N2 molecule adsorbed on the surface, regardless of whether a proton is involved or not. E 0 ≈ - 4.16 V vs. NHE (7) or E 0 ≈ - 3.37 V vs. RHE at pH = 14 The above potentials indicate that there is an inherently high energy barrier in the initial stage of hydrogenation in solution, so the electrochemical nitrogen reduction reaction is thermodynamically difficult. In addition to the higher NRR potential, the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) side reaction competes with the NRR. The limit potentials of the NRR and HER are compared as a descriptor. For the HER, the descriptor is H* binding energy, but the adsorption energy of N and H are different. N* adsorption energy is selected as the descriptor of the two reactions [27]. As shown in Fig. 3 , the overpotentials of NRR are larger than those of the HER; therefore, different surfaces of a single metal remain great challenges for ammonia synthesis. Except for a single metal site, bimetallic sites can regulate the interactions between metals, which regulates the ratio of the intermediate products, *N2H and *NH2. Huang et al. used density functional theory (DFT) calculations of large-scale systems with 2D phthalocyanine (Pc) as a carrier to establish a comparison chart of the stability, activity, and selectivity of metal dimers, including homonuclear diatomic catalysts and heteronuclear diatomic catalysts [28]. The author considered 30 metal atoms, including 27 transition metal atoms (except lanthanides, Tc, Cd, and Hg) and three main group metal atoms (Al, Ga, and Bi) as the central atoms of a two-dimensional phthalocyanine network. The excellent catalytic activity and metal properties made these BACs promising and efficient NRR catalysts. Among them, five catalysts, Ti2-Pc, V2-Pc, TiVPc, VCr-Pc, and VTa-Pc effectively inhibited the HER, which showed limiting potentials of −0.75, −0.39, −0.74, −0.85, and −0.47 V, respectively. Similar to other catalytic reactions, the NRR process includes three steps: i) the adsorption of N2 molecules; ii) the dissociation of NN triple bonds and hydrogenation; and iii) the desorption of ammonia molecules or other products from the catalyst surface. Since N2 has two nitrogen atoms, there will be different adsorption and hydrogenation processes, which proceed via two paths: a dissociative pathway or an associative pathway, as shown in Fig. 4 [15,29,30]. For the dissociative pathway, the cracking of the NN bond occurs first, followed by hydrogenation, and finally the releases of NH3 from the catalyst surface. According to the hydrogenation reaction sequence and the adsorption mode on the catalyst surface, the associative pathway can be divided into an alternative pathway, distal pathway, and enzymatic pathway. In the alternative pathway, two N atoms are hydrogenated simultaneously and are eventually released as NH3. In the distal pathway, distal N atoms are first hydrogenated and released as NH3. Then, the remaining N atoms are hydrogenated in turn, and finally, NH3 is released. In the enzymatic pathway, two N atoms are adsorbed on the catalyst surface in a bridge, and then the two N atoms are hydrogenated separately until NH3 is formed. In the case of biological nitrogenases and some catalysts that can strongly bind nitrogen, dinitrogen molecules bind to the catalyst surface at both ends and are hydrogenated enzymatically [29]. The formation of hydrazine (N2H4) is only an intermediate in the enzymatic route, while *N2H4 desorption from the catalyst surface is usually a high-energy step, which makes N2H4 mostly a secondary product (see Fig. 4). 3 NRR experiment setup Since the earliest experiments on the electrochemical synthesis of NH3 ammonia in the 1960s, researchers have continuously explored experimental techniques and catalyst types [6,31,32]. Nevertheless, the efficiency and output of synthetic ammonia are still very low. It is because ammonia production is too low to confirm whether electrochemical or other nitrogen-fixing nitrogen fixation. For example, nitrogen in the air, nitrogen sources in raw materials (nitrates, amines, nitrites, and nitrogen oxides), experimental equipment, and the experimental environment will all be tested for ammonia [33,34]. Therefore, a series of verification and exclusion work is essential to eliminate environmental pollution during catalyst synthesis and NRR experiments. Another way to confirm the source of nitrogen is isotope labeling [35]. Only when the prerequisite work is done can the accuracy of the NRR results be ensured, which provides a better reference for future researchers. 3.1 NRR device factor The different types of NRR electrochemical cells that have been reported can be roughly divided into four categories: back-to-back cells, polymer electrolyte membrane (PEM)-type cells, H-type cells, and single-chamber cells (Fig. 5 ) [30]. Back-to-back cells and (PEM)-type cells can naturally avoid HER because there is no water at the cathode. The back-to-back cell consists of two porous electrodes, separated by a layer of a dense membrane (such as a Nafion membrane and anion exchange membrane (AEM)) [36,37]. In this solid electrolyte system, the proton supply can be well controlled to suppress protons. For example, Renner et al. designed a back-to-back battery for the production of NH3. The battery used Fe, FeNi, or Ni nanoparticles as the cathode catalyst and AEM as the electrolyte [38]. Its operating principle involved the generation of protons and electrons in the chamber of the liquid, which acted on the solid layers (that is, the membrane layer, the catalyst layer, and the gas diffusion layer) to convert N2 to NH3. Back-to-back cells are two-electrode systems, whose electrolytic potential may fluctuate. PEM-type cells introduce a reference electrode to stabilize the cathode potential. For H-type cells and single-chamber cells, the chamber is generally filled with an electrolyte, where the catalyst is in direct contact with the electrolyte, and hydrogen evolution occurs at the cathode to form a competitive reaction. The hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) produces too many protons, which eventually leads to a low Faradaicy efficiency. Compared with a single cell, an H-type cell has an extra diaphragm layer that blocks the penetration of ammonia between the cathode and the anode, preventing the further oxidation of ammonia at the anode. Most researchers currently use H-shaped pools. However, the competitive HER is still difficult to eliminate, so other conditions, such as reaction pressure and catalyst design, have been used to solve this problem [39,40]. The electrolytes used in electrocatalysis can be either acidic (0.05 M H2SO4 or 0.1 M HCl), neutral (0.1 M PBS, or 0.1 M Na2SO4), or alkaline (0.1 M KOH). The effects of electrolyte pH and counterion on NRR activity and selectivity have been widely reported by researchers, but there is no uniform conclusion. In the case of N-doped porous carbon electrocatalysts, Wu et al. demonstrated that the NRR performance in 0.1 M KOH was better than in 0.1 M HCl from 25 °C to 60 °C. The concentration of KOH also affects the performance (0.1 M is better than 0.5 M) [41]. At the same time, other researchers have reported that the NRR electrocatalytic performance is very similar over a wide pH range from acidic to alkaline, but a higher performance was obtained at lower pH values [42]. This change may be due to the differences in the cell, the inherent characteristics of different catalysts, the effects of impurities in the electrolyte, and the local pH gradient caused by the reaction [43]. At the same time, the electrolyte provides opportunities to improve the choice of electrocatalytic NRR. It has been shown that Li+ can suppress the HER and enhance the NRR (in 0.5 M Li2SO4 and LiClO4 electrolytes) [44]. On the other hand, during the electrochemical synthesis of NH3 at ambient temperature and pressure, the low solubility of N2 in water and the often severe HER in aqueous systems leads to a low NRR Faradaic efficiency. Ionic liquids can solve this problem well. Compared with conventional molecular solvents, ionic liquids have good electrical conductivities, strong electrostatic fields, unique microenvironments, and other characteristics including the existence of multiple weak interactions within ionic liquids, which can greatly suppress the HER and improve the NRR efficiency. Studies have shown that ionic liquids can greatly improve the solubility of N2, which may provide the possibility to improve the efficiency of the NRR [45,46]. The use of ionic liquids is also largely dependent on their ionic structure. MacFarlane et al. used [P6,6,6,14][eFAP] ionic liquids to increase the Faradaic efficiency of the NRR up to 60%, which can be used to further develop nitrogen fixation methods [47]. In addition to the types of reaction cells and electrolytes used during the NRR test, which affect the nitrogen fixation efficiency, the temperature and pressure also play roles during ammonia synthesis. The ammonia synthesis reaction is a reversible process, and changing the reaction conditions will destroy the chemical equilibrium. According to Le Chatelier’s principle, increasing the pressure can shift the equilibrium due to the smaller volume. Nitrogen fixation involves a reduction in the gas volume, and the final ammonia gas forms NH4 + with water, so the increase of pressure could move reaction to generate NH4 +. In contrast, the HER increases the volume, and pressurization can suppress the formation of hydrogen, which will help improve the selectivity of the NRR. At the same time, pressurization also increases the solubility of N2 in a solution. These are beneficial measures [39]. For temperature, the Haber-Bosch reaction is exothermic and limited by the equilibrium number. Because the dissociation temperature of the N2 molecule is extremely high, the high temperature will shift the reaction equilibrium to favor the decomposition of NH3. Zhang et al. proposed a dual temperature zone catalytic strategy and synthesized a TiO2− x H y /Fe composite whose apparent temperature reached 495 °C under illumination. Due to localized surface plasmon resonance (SPR) heating effect, including a hot zone (Fe) and cold zone, the temperature difference between (TiO2− x H y ) reached 137 °C [48]. The hot carriers on a Fe “nano necklace” can effectively dissociate N2, and the TiO2− x H y in series can quickly capture dissociated N through a continuous hydrogenation reaction, which significantly inhibits the reverse equilibrium reaction. 3.2 NRR electrocatalyst factor At present, there is no effective catalyst for the electrocatalytic conversion of N2 to NH3 under ambient conditions. During the NRR process, the large overpotential of N2 and the competitive HER result in a low NH3 production rate and poor selectivity, respectively. The catalytic performance of NRR catalysts can be improved by fundamentally changing the characteristics of the original catalyst. We have summarized several factors that affect catalyst activity at the microscale, including size, electronic, coordination, and orientation effects. 3.2.1 Size effects The catalyst size is related to its effective specific surface area. The larger the size, the less active area is exposed, which results in a low reactivity. The smaller the size, the more active sites are exposed, and the reactivity increases. Both theoretical and experimental studies have shown that Au nanostructures can catalyze the reduction of nitrogen to NH3 [27]. The structure of Au can be adjusted to improve the nitrogen fixation efficiency. Wang et al. synthesized Au nanoflowers with a size of about 900 nm by the rapid reduction of HAuCl4 [49]. The resulting gold nanoflowers were assembled from interleaved nanosheets, which provided abundant active sites for the NRR. Under a bias voltage of −0.2 V vs. RHE, the maximum ammonia yield was 25.57 μg h−1 mg−1 cat., the Faradaic efficiency was 6.05%, and it displayed good catalytic nitrogen reduction activity. Under ultrasonic conditions, ascorbic acid reduced chloroauric acid to gold nanoflowers in 5 s, where gum arabic and potassium bromide played an important role; however, the resulting Au nanoflowers were large, which limited the number of catalytically active sites. Mostafa A. El-Sayed et al. synthesized gold nanocrystals with different morphologies and studied the effect of different morphological structures on NRR performance [50]. The research team synthesized gold nanorods (AuNRs), gold nanospheres (AuNSs), gold nanocubes (AuNCs), and gold nanocages (AuHNCs) using different methods, and found that a gold nanocage (35 nm) showed the highest catalytic activity during nitrogen reduction. When using solid nanoparticles as nanocatalysts, the catalytic reaction involve atoms from the outer surface of the nanocatalyst, while for hollow nanocatalysts, the reaction occurs on both the outer surface and the inner surface [51–57]; therefore, the hollow nanocatalyst shows better nitrogen fixation performance because of its larger active surface area. By confining the reactants in a cage, the reaction activity in the hollow nanocatalyst cavity can be increased (cage effect), which increased the steady-state concentration. In some cases, the inner surface may not be as well-covered by blocking agents as the outer surface, and therefore may be more catalytically active. In this case, the reaction rate is higher because the reactants are enclosed inside the cage [58–60]. When the catalyst is reduced to the size of quantum dots, due to quantum effects, they will exhibit physical and chemical properties different from those of macroscopic materials. Recently, researchers have made progress in the synthesis of ammonia in the field of quantum dots. CoO has poor HER activity but is beneficial to the NRR activity. Chu et al. used CoO quantum dots on graphene for the electrocatalytic synthesis of ammonia; and reported a high NH3 yield of 21.5 mg h−1 mg−1 and an FE of 8.3% at −0.6 V vs. RHE [61]. Due to the presence of more active sites, SnO2 quantum dots show better NRR activity than submicrometer particles when combined with graphene [62,63]. Thus, when the catalyst size is reduced to quantum dot dimensions, the catalytic activity is greatly improved, and they can preferably with the conductive substrate which improve the stability of charge transport compounds and catalysts. Single-atom catalysts can achieve the maximum exposure center per unit mass compared with similar bulky catalysts. Atomic-scale catalysts have higher activities, higher selectivities, and are more durable [64,65]. Therefore, this new type of catalyst has become a frontier in the field of catalysis, which has attracted researchers’ attention. And single-atom catalysis has been widely used in other fields, such as oxygen reduction reaction, HER, oxygen evolution reaction, CO2 reduction reaction and so on [66–68]. Loading single Au atoms on an N-doped C substrate for electrocatalytic NRR can significantly improve the Faradaic efficiency (12.3%) [69]. The pyrolysis of Ru-containing ZIF-8 to obtain single atom Ru can achieve NH3 production rates up to 120.9 μg h−1 mg−1 cat. (Fig. 6 a and b) [70]. Due to the scarcity of precious metal resources, many researchers are concerned about the use of transition metals. A series of studies have used mono-atomic Fe-Nx structure [29,71,72], single-atom Cu [73], and Mo [74,75]. Synthetic methods generally include wet chemical methods [76], confined pyrolysis methods [77], and carrier-assisted method [78,79]. The synthesis of single-atom catalysts has drawn attention due to the high atom utilization rate, rapid charge transfer, and great progress for enhancing electrochemical catalytic reactions. The size effect has been investigated in the field of catalysis because it is related to the apparent active area. When the number of active sites decreases and the exposure gradually increases, the corresponding overpotential becomes smaller, and the catalytic reaction becomes faster. 3.2.2 Electronic effects Some measures (heteroatom doping, heterostructure, etc.) change the electronic state of the active sites and affinity of the catalyst host and cause a series of electronic effects, which can change the catalytic active site and electron transport characteristics. These electronic effects ultimately regulate the catalytic characteristics of the entire catalyst, thereby improving the NH3 synthesis efficiency and selectivity. This lays a foundation for electrocatalyst applications. 3.2.2.1 Heteroatom doping Heteroatoms can form a special coordination environment and electronic structure, which can increase the number of NRR active centers and reduce the NRR rate, which determines the step barrier. Therefore, heteroatom doping can be used as an effective strategy to prepare electrocatalysts. Depending on the dopant, heteroatom doping can be divided into metal doping and non-metal doping. We summarize recent NRR catalysts doped with heteroatoms in Table 1 . In recent years, there has been much theoretical research on the application of transition metal-doped catalysts in the NRR, including the use of single-atom and bimetallic dopants [28,80,81]. In-depth studies have investigated the mechanism of the NRR reaction, as well as the difference in the performance of the catalyst after doping with different transition metal atoms. This also provides a certain theoretical basis for subsequent experiments. Taking the 2D expanded phthalocyanine (Pc) substrate as an example, Huang et al. adopted homonuclear and heteronuclear diatomic anchors respectively [28]. Using N2H* adsorption free energy as the activity description symbol, the number of possible catalyst candidates was reduced from 900 to less than 100, which reduced the time needed for experimental investigations. The difference in activity was due to the different lowest-energy positions generated during the coordination of different metal atoms, which reconstructed the electron distribution. Metal doping disperses the dopant at the atomic level to form a single-metal or bimetallic catalyst. Transition metals are cheap and abundant, and they are used as dopants to change the surface electronic structure and anchor the catalytic center, which can reduce the critical fracture barrier of inert N2 molecules [82,83]. Fe-doped two-dimensional SnO2 can be used as an NRR catalyst with outstanding activity [84]. Due to the introduction of Fe, the oxygen vacancies on the surface of SnO2 are reduced, which was confirmed by the Sn 3d XPS spectrum. The same conclusion was also obtained from the O 1s XPS spectrum and electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra, where the intensity decreased after Fe doping. Fe doping sites are anchored at surface oxygen vacancies. Another part of Fe is doped in the SnO2 lattice, which can be determined from atomic-level high-angle annular dark field-scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM) images. The Fe anchored to surface oxygen vacancies are used as the active sites, while lattice-doped Fe is used to enhance the electron transfer to the catalyst. Fe doping changes the SnO2 electronic structure, whether it is the original oxygen vacancies on the surface or the regular crystal form in the crystal lattice, so that the catalyst can activate N2 molecules and reduce the reaction energy barrier, thereby improving the NRR activity. Besides, the doped catalyst may also polarize the interface, which leads to NN bond fracture. For example, protruding Fe atoms are present on a single-layer MoS2 nanosheet, and its crystal structure is shown in Fig. 7 a [85]. After N2 adsorbs on the dopant Fe, an electric field (EF) is generated, which induces N2 polarization that can be detected by in situ Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR). Then, the N2 charge distribution is not uniform, and a dipole moment is generated. When a potential is applied, activated electrons are transferred from Fe to N2, which breaks so that the NN bond. Since the d-orbitals of transition metal atoms are more likely to form metal-H bonds and there will be interference from the HER; thus, non-metals have attracted increasing attention. Among them, low-cost B which contains a lone pair of electrons and empty orbital, has properties similar to transition metals. When doped into a carbon material, B can be positively-charged to provide an empty orbital. According to the Lewis theory, N2 is a weak Lewis base, and the production of Lewis acid sites (the empty orbital of B) is considered to be an advantageous strategy for the reduction of N2 [86]. The doping of boron in a graphene framework redistributes the electron density, and the electron-deficient boron sites have a higher binding affinity for N2 (Fig. 7b) [87]. Since N is more electronegative than carbon, it is generally believed that doping can regulate the charge density of C, which is more positively charged, which can improve the adsorption of N2. Nitrogen-doped porous carbon membranes can electrochemically catalyze N2 to NH3 under acidic conditions [88,89]. The doping of graphene with highly electronegative Cl atoms redistributes the electrons of adjacent carbon atoms to regulate the active sites of graphdiyne [90]. When multiple heteroatoms are used as dopants, they can synergistically regulate electrons [91]. Researchers have investigated many doped metal-doped and non-metal doped catalysts. The introduction of these dopants, including single atoms and diatoms, is conducive to the reintegration of catalyst electrons, which form new catalytically-active centers and improve the activity and selectivity of the NRR. 3.2.2.2 Heterostructure Compared with single-component catalysts, heterostructured catalysts can more effectively control the strain between the interfaces and coordinate the electronic structure due to the interactions between the different components of the heterostructure [94–96]. Chen et al. constructed a donor–acceptor pair of Ni and Au nanoparticles supported on nitrogen-doped carbon [97]. The authors developed a direct current replacement method to prepare catalysts adjacent to Au and Ni nanoparticles. When only Ni was used, ammonia production was negligible; however, when a small amount of Au was combined, the ammonia production increased rapidly, showing that Au plays the role of a catalytic active center in the NRR. The Ni 2p XPS spectrum shows that in the presence of Au, the Ni peak will move toward a large binding energy, and as the amount of Au decreases, the Au peak will shift toward a low binding energy and increase in intensity. The lowest amount of Au is Au0.5/Ni, which showed the best NH3 yield of 1.6 μg h−1 mg−1 cat. and a Faradaic efficiency of 14.2%, which indicates that there is strong electron-coupling between Ni and Au nanoparticles. Ni acts as an electron donor, Au acts as an electron acceptor, and the electrons rich surface of Au enhances the NRR activity. Stacking different two-dimensional materials forms van der Waals heterojunctions, which are widely used in many fields, such as photovoltaic and energy storage devices, due to their interesting electronic effects [87,98–100]. Two-dimensional transition metal sulfides have an ultra-high specific surface area and special physicochemical properties and show great potential for use in catalytic reactions [101,102]. For example, MoS2 and a reduced graphene oxide (RGO) hybrid (MoS2-RGO/CPE) showed excellent electrocatalytic activity in the NRR [103]. The layered structure was well-combined, which was confirmed by TEM and EDX elemental mapping images. After the introduction of RGO, MoS2 exposed more active sites. The maximum ammonia production rate of MoS2-RGO/CPE reached 24.82 μg h−1 mg−1 cat. and the Faradaic efficiency reached 4.58% at −0.45 V in 0.1 M LiClO4 solution. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) showed that MoS2-RGO/CPE has a smaller semicircle radius than MoS2/CPE, indicating that the MoS2-RGO composite has a lower charge transport resistance. The strong interactions between the MoS2 and RGO layers promoted charge transport. Similarly, a highly-conductive species, Ti3C2T x (T = F, OH) MXene, a two-dimensional catalyst, showed effective NRR performance [104,105]. There are interaction between the two catalysts that are compounded with each other, which enhance the activity of NRR. TiO2 nanoparticles were hydrothermally grown in situ on Ti3C2Tx MXene nanosheets to form a TiO2/Ti3C2T x nanohybrid [92]. The HRTEM images showed that particles with a 40 nm diameter grew on the flakes. The corresponding XRD patterns and EDS element mapping images confirmed they were TiO2 nanoparticles. The XPS Ti 2p spectrum showed that the number of Ti-O bonds increased after the formation of TiO2/Ti3C2T x , indicating that Ti3C2T x was converted to TiO2 during the hydrothermal process. The interactions between Ti3C2T x and TiO2 grown in situ were strong, giving rise to better activity in the NRR. TiO2/Ti3C2T x /CP has a maximum NH3 yield of 26.32 μg h−1 mg−1 cat. and a Faradaic efficiency of 8.42% at −0.6 V in 0.1 M HCl. The existence of this heterostructure gave TiO2/Ti3C2T x a strong electrochemical stability for the NRR for at least 24 h, indicating that it is stable. Besides, the electronic rectification between the metal and the substrate changes the electronic structure of the metal, which is usually called the Mott-Schottky effect. It is present in the design of many catalysts [106–108]. By applying this effect, the electron density of Cu nanoparticles can be adjusted to improve the catalytic NRR ability of low-activity Cu. Cu and polyimide hybrids (Cu/PI) were synthesized by a wet chemical method, using heat-treated polyimide nanoflowers as a support (schematic diagram in Fig. 8 a) [109]. As the temperature of the heat-treated PI increased, the band gap of Cu/PI becomes narrower, which was confirmed by the ultraviolet–visible absorption spectrum (Fig. 8b). Cu nanoparticles were integrated into polyimide nanoflowers, and the particle size was about 30 nm, which was obtained from the TEM image (Fig. 8c). When applied to the NRR, Cu/PI-300 produced an NH3 yield rate of 12.4 µg h−1 cm−2 and a Faradaic efficiency of 6.56%, which is higher than Cu/C. To further study the reasons for the higher catalytic activity between Cu and the support, the electronic structure was simulated by density functional theory (DFT). The electron density difference (EDD) (Fig. 8d-e) indicates that the semiconductor carrier PI can attract more electrons from Cu than the carbon support, indicating that Cu forms a rectifying contact with the PI semiconductor. The energy band structure diagrams of Cu/PI-300, Cu/PI-400, and Cu/PI-600 were obtained from the ultraviolet photoelectron spectra (UPS), UV–vis absorption spectra and Mott-Schottky plote (Fig. 8f). The PI-600 sample was highly concentrated with organic carbon with a narrow band gap, and the conductivity was improved. Besides, the work function of Cu in PI-300 (from UPS results) showed the greatest improvement. Therefore, it can be concluded from the energy band structure that PI-300 can capture more electrons from Cu nanoparticles due to the Mott-Schottky effect between Cu and PI. This electronic rectification effect was also confirmed by XPS. The Cu 2p 3/2 XPS peak of Cu/PI-300 underwent a large shift to a higher binding energy, so PI-300 can attract more electrons from the deposited Cu nanoparticles. This Mott-Schottky interfacial contact between the metal and the semiconductor modulates the electron density of Cu nanoparticles to preferentially adsorb OH− in alkaline solutions, thereby inhibiting the HER. At the same time, the electron-deficient Cu nanoparticles significantly enhance the pre-adsorption of N2 molecules, thereby increasing the generation rate of NH3. 3.2.3 Coordination effect In coordination-catalyzed reactions, active center atoms are usually coordinatively unsaturated, providing many opportunities to improve the catalytic activity and selectivity, while well-defined active sites provide an ideal model system for an in-depth understanding of the working mechanism [110,111]. The design concept of coordinatively unsaturated catalysts is applied in many fields due to its good catalytic activity [112–116]. Among electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction catalysts, coordination effects can include amorphous and vacant materials. 3.2.3.1 Amorphous Amorphous materials have no long-range order in their internal structure due to their rich active surfaces, abundant body defects, and unique local electronic structures, making them ideal catalyst candidates for various electrochemical reactions [117]. Many unsaturated coordination sites are formed by dangling bonds, and the introduced defects give amorphous materials greatly enhanced activities. The high density of the defect sites and the lower energy barrier in amorphous catalysts have provided remarkable performances in various electrocatalytic applications [118,119]. An amorphous Bi4V2O11-crystalline CeO2 composite was used in the NRR [120]. By adjusting the ratio of the Ce source and Bi source via single spinneret electrospinning with subsequent calcination, the authors obtained a Bi4V2O11/CeO2 hybrid with an amorphous phase (BVC-A) and crystalline phase (BVC-C) (Fig. 9 a). Amorphous Bi4V2O11 has more defects throughout its nanofibers, as demonstrated by HRTEM. The XPS spectrum of BVC-A showed that the binding energy of Bi and V is lower, indicating more defects. The availability of local electrons in the amorphous state was enhanced by π-electron back-donation, which facilitated nitrogen activation to form dinitrogen ligands for the cleavage of nitrogen molecules [121]. Similar conclusions were obtained by Raman spectroscopy, where the BVC-A Raman band shifts, indicating that the rich dangling bonds of amorphous Bi4V2O11 changed the bonding length and angle to produce a distorted lattice. These amorphous states provided active centers and reduced the energy barrier [122]. It was found that amorphous Bi4V2O11 showed better performance than Bi4V2O11 due to its good crystallization. The ammonia production rate of BVC-A reached 23.21 µg h−1 mg−1 cat. and its Faradaic efficiency reached 10.16% at −0.2 V, which was almost 2 times higher than BVC-C (Fig. 9b-c). The introduction of the amorphous phase became the active center of the catalyst and also further promoted interfacial charge transfer. The previous section mentioned that Au displays a certain NRR catalytic activity, but it is limited due to its low NH3 yield and low Faradaic efficiency [123]. Amorphous Au is more active during catalytic reaction. Amorphous Au nanoparticles can be prepared by the co-reduction method, in which CeO x converts crystalline Au into amorphous Au and combines with RGO to obtain a catalyst (a-Au/CeO x -RGO) with good NRR performance at ambient temperature (Fig. 9d) [124]. Compared with the crystalline Au deposited directly on the surface of RGO (c-Au/RGO), amorphous Au has greater structural distortion, resulting in higher ammonia yield (8.3 µg h−1 mg−1) and Faradaic efficiency (10.10%). The introduction of other inert metals to control the crystallinity of active metals has also become a popular strategy to improve the NRR. PdCu amorphous nanoclusters were prepared by the synergistic reduction of metal precursors and GO by mixing reducing agents, and they showed novel electrocatalytic NRR activity (Fig. 9e) [125]. rGO acts as a dispersing metal in the composite, which prevents serious agglomeration, allowing the preparation of Pd0.2Cu0.8/rGO particles with an average size of about 1.7 nm. The XRD spectrum of the sample showed that besides the peak of RGO, the metals did not display a peak, indicating that Pd0.2Cu0.8 was amorphous. The high-resolution XPS spectrum shows that the Pd peak in Pd0.2Cu0.8/rGO shifted to lower binding energy than Pd/rGO, while the binding energy of Cu in Pd0.2Cu0.8/rGO shifted to a higher binding energy than Cu/rGO due to charge transfer between Pd and Cu atoms. The PdCu amorphous clusters regulated the weakening of Pd's adsorption of H, which accelerated hydrogen desorption. The dangling bonds on amorphous materials provided more active sites than the dangling bonds on crystalline materials, which further increased the likelihood of nitrogen activation. Pd0.2Cu0.8/rGO shows an excellent NRR activity, and the NRR yield at −0.2 V vs. RHE is 2.80 µg h−1 mg−1 cat. at room temperature and atmospheric pressure, which is much higher than that of the single-metal catalysts (Pd/rGO and Cu/rGO). It can be seen that amorphous catalysts may contain more dangling bonds, which give them more catalytically active sites. 3.2.3.2 Vacancies The introduction of vacancies changes the energy band structure and electronic structure of a catalyst, and thereby changes the catalytic pathway. Below, we introduce research progress into the effects of different types of defects. Many studies have shown that the oxygen vacancy concentration on the surface of metal oxides can alter the surface electronic properties and bandgap structure by exposing additional coordination unsaturated bonds and improve the catalytic activity [126,127]. Oxygen vacancies can capture metastable electrons and inject them into the antibonding orbital of N2 to achieve electron transfer on oxygen deficiencies. This strategy is widely used in transition metal oxides, which greatly improve the catalytic activity, and NRR electrocatalysts are also included. TiO2 containing oxygen defects was grown on Ti mesh to create an NRR catalyst (Fig. 10 a) [128]. Due to the existence of oxygen vacancies, Ti3+ became the active center, which increased the adsorption and activation of N2 and showed a high catalytic activity. Similarly, in CeO2, the reduction of hydrogen to obtain oxygen-deficient CeO2 nanorods (r-CeO2) for the NRR showed good catalytic activity (16.4 μg h−1 mg−1 cat. at −0.5 V vs. RHE) and selectivity (FE = 3.7%) [129]. When oxygen vacancies are enriched on a catalyst surface, the crystallinity of the original oxide structure is destroyed, and it changes from a crystalline structure to an amorphous structure. Together with the conductivity and catalytic activity of the metal, NRR catalysis can be improved. Au metal is used as the inner core, and the semiconductor oxide that controls oxygen vacancies is used as the shell to prepare a core–shell structure. This is a promising NRR catalytic strategy. Au was used as the core and SnO2 with oxygen vacancies was used as the shell to create Au@SnO2, which showed an excellent NH3 yield (21.9 μg h−1 mg−1 cat.) and Faradaic efficiency (15.2% at −0.2 VRHE) due to abundant oxygen vacancies (Fig. 8b) [130]. This study showed the surface oxygen-enriched vacancies significantly increased the adsorption of N2 and increased the overall binding energy of the d-band center of the overall catalyst, which enhanced the NRR activity. The abundant oxygen vacancies, unsaturated Sn sites, and exposed Au atoms cooperate to improve the N2 adsorption and the activation step of the speed control step, which accelerated the electron transport. Therefore, the NRR performance was improved. Oxygen vacancies can capture metastable electrons and inject them into the antibonding orbital of N2 to transfer electrons; however, oxygen vacancies are very unstable because they are easily oxidized by water or oxygen [131,132]. Therefore, it challenging for the oxygen vacancies to show both a high activity and high stability. Some recently-reported NRR catalysts containing oxygen vacancies have shown increased stability [133]. Both oxygen vacancies and grain boundaries can adjust the energy band structure of WO3 nanocrystals and promote the electron adsorption of N2 by enhancing covalent [133]. The inherent advantages of transition metal sulfides have been widely demonstrated in the field of catalysis, and they also have good performance when used in the NRR catalysis [134–136]. Defect-rich MoS2 can improve the adsorption of N2 and boost the NRR reaction (Fig. 10c and d) [137]. S-rich defects exist on the periphery of MoS2, which distributes charge near defects, which become catalytically-active sites that increase the rate of the NRR. Oxygen and sulfur vacancies have similar chemical properties, so the formation of sulfur vacancies can induce the adsorption and activation of N2 and also affect the energy band structure and electronic structure of transition metal sulfides, which ultimately affect the catalytic NRR performance [138]. Researchers have found that some N vacancies have similar characteristics [139]. N vacancies can affect the electronic structure and energy band structure of the catalyst, which, in turn, affects the catalytic activity. Theoretical calculations have shown that various transition metal nitrides have potential activity for NRR [140–142]. By annealing in a H2/Ar mixture gas, ultra-thin two-dimensional W2N3 nanosheets rich in N vacancies (NV-W2N3) were obtained, and they exhibited an excellent NRR activity (11.66 ± 0.98 µg h−1 mg−1 cata) and selectivity (FE = 11.67 ± 0.93% at −0.2 V vs. RHE) (Fig. 10e and f) [143]. The high-resolution XPS data indicate that the valence state of W in W2N3 treated by H2 was reduced because the existence of N vacancies changed the electronic structure of W. Furthermore, the L3-edge curve of W in the X-ray absorption fine structure spectra (EXAFS) proved that the W-N bond coordination number decreased from 4.3 to 4.0, which also shows the existence of N vacancies in the catalyst. Theoretical calculations confirmed that the N vacancy sites are electron-deficient locations. The lone electron in the N2 molecule can be accommodated by the electron-deficient region. During activation, the electrons of W will contribute to the antibonding orbital of N2 and activate adsorbed N2. A non-metallic polymer carbon nitride (PCN) is used as the base material, and introducing N vacancy defects and adjusting π electron delocalization in the entire conjugated structure, can activate the conversion of N2 (Fig. 10g) [144]. In the XRD patterns of PCN and PCN-NV, the diffraction peak of PCN-NV is wider, and its intensity is weaker indicating that PCN-NV has a rich defect structure (Fig. 8h). The enhanced enhancement of the EPR signal indicates that the paramagnetic intensity increased, directly proving the existence of N vacancies (Fig. 10i). At the same time, the calculation results showed that after introducing N vacancies into PCN, electrons were transferred from surrounding carbon atoms to adsorbed N2, which weakened the NN bond and increased the bond length, thereby activating N2. This increased the NH3 production rate (8.09 µg h−1 mg−1) and increased the Faradaic efficiency (11.59% at −0.2 V vs RHE) when using PCN-NV; therefore, N vacancies in the catalyst activated N2 and served as catalytically active centers. Similarly, nitrogen vacancies also have stability issues. To solve this, researchers have doped other atoms to stabilize the vacancies [145]. The presence of vacancies also increases the number of dopants and active sites. In addition to the sulfur vacancies, oxygen vacancies, nitrogen vacancies, and other anion vacancies mentioned above, cation vacancies are also formed by some materials. Cation vacancies can adjust the coordination structure so that the charges around vacancies are rearranged and become catalytic active center [146,147]. The intrinsic defects of the material become active centers. Graphene can be etched by HF to obtain defect-rich graphene, which provides active sites for the NRR and also activates N2 molecules [148]. The carbon atoms around carbon vacancies are more conducive to the adsorption of nitrogen molecules and the elongation of NN bonds. Other metals with semiconductor properties, such as Bi, have a low activity and low electron accessibility, which can inhibit the HER and increase the efficiency of ammonia synthesis [46]. To improve the activity of Bi, low-temperature plasma bombardment was used to create a Bi catalyst that preferentially exposed the Bi (1 1 0) plane, and many lattice defects were prepared from the oxidation precursor [149]. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations showed that Bi defects enable the active site to adsorb and activate N2, allowing them to favorably form N2H*, which promoted the NRR. Besides the synthetic catalysts with the vacancies we have introduced above, other vacancies form during the NRR. Wen et al. synthesized N-doped carbon coated on γ-Fe2O3 nanoparticles supported on carbon fiber (γ-Fe2O3-NC/CF) [133]. However, after the NRR test, the peak intensity in the Raman spectrum decreased, and the Fe3+ peak area in XPS was significantly increased compared with the original Fe2O3, which all indicate the formation of cation vacancies during the NRR. A comparison of the HRTEM images before and after the reaction showed that the lattice structure was distorted during the test. Since the NRR test used an HCl electrolyte, some of the Fe ions overflowed from the lattice during the test to form cation vacancies that promoted the NRR. This produced a considerable ammonia yield of 11.7 × 10−10 mo1 s−1 cm−2 and Faradaic efficiency (FE) of 12.28%. Above, we have summarized the regulation of different vacancies in NRR catalysts. Recently, researchers have synergistically used doping and vacancies to regulate the active sites of electrocatalysts. The B-doped and S vacancies in VS2 increase the basal plane activity toward the NRR, which promotes the NRR and suppresses the HER [150]. The combination of MnO2 nanoflakes with rich oxygen vacancies and B doping lead to an improved conductivity and enhanced intrinsic NRR activity [151]. DFT results further revealed that the enhanced NRR activity arose from the B dopants and oxygen vacancies, which created an asymmetric charge distribution that activated adjacent Mn atoms and stabilized and reduced the reaction energy barrier. The doping of other oxides also showed this phenomenon. For example, in Fe-doped CeO2, doping generated a large number of oxygen vacancies, which exposed more active sites and promoted charge transport, ultimately promoting the NRR performance [152]. The above results show that the mutual synergistic effect of doping combined with the vacancy effect jointly enhanced the catalytic activity. Compared with the single-vacancy effect, this improves both the stability and catalytic activity. From this, we can conclude that all types of vacancy defects regulate their surrounding electronic structure, thus becoming an active center, which is conducive to the adsorption of N2 and the transfer of electrons. Adjusting the vacancies in a catalyst improves its performance. At the same time, the role of vacancies in catalytic reactions will be studied in greater depth to explain the role of vacancies. 3.2.3.3 Orientation effects A typical catalytic reaction is closely related to the orientation of the catalyst surface [153]. Studies have found that the stepped surface contains active sites for N2 dissociation [124]. Similar defect engineering and plane orientation on metal-based catalysts provide an effective strategy to improve N2 adsorption on these active sites, thereby reducing the energy barrier for N2 dissociation [5]. Inspired by nitrogenase fixation in nature, Mo may be an effective catalyst for ammonia synthesis [154]. Wang et al. used electrochemical deposition to prepare Mo nanoparticles with (1 1 0) and (2 1 1) crystal plane orientations. Studies have found that (1 1 0)-oriented Mo more easily adsorbs nitrogen than hydrogen, while for (2 1 1)-oriented Mo, it adsorbs hydrogen more easily than nitrogen, therefore, Mo with a (1 1 0) orientation has the best catalytic performance. Its nano-scale surface structure can also produce a higher density of step sites on the surface, which helps improve the catalytic activity. It is for these reasons that the ammonia production rate of (1 1 0)-oriented Mo reaches 3.09 × 10−11 mo1 s−1 cm−2 and an FE of 0.72% under an applied potential of −0.49 V vs. RHE. Zhang et al. synthesized tetrahedral gold nanorods (THH Au NRs) with high-index facets that exhibited excellent NRR activity [123]. THH Au NRs were enclosed by a stepped facet, composed of (2 1 0) and (3 1 0) sub-facets, as shown in Fig. 11 a. The atomic arrangements on the THH Au facets were measured by spherical aberration-corrected transmission electron microscopy, and the high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) image is shown in Fig. 11b. Due to the exposure of {7 3 0}, the THH Au NRs showed an NH3 yield rate of 1.648 μg h−1 cm−2 and a N2H4·H2O yield rate of 0.102 μg h−1 cm−2 at −0.2 V vs. RHE (Fig. 11c). DFT calculations have shown that exposing these active surfaces enables N2 molecules to form more stable Au-N bonds on the Au surface and break NN triple bonds (Fig. 11d). Therefore, catalysts with specific crystal faces exposed promote the adsorption and activation of nitrogen molecules. A study of these oriented crystal faces may have great potential for the preparation of high-yield NH3 catalysts. 4 Conclusions and outlook In general, the electrochemical NRR to ammonia has made tremendous progress in terms of experimental equipment and catalyst selection, filling many gaps in this field. In theory, NRR is a thermodynamically difficult reaction at normal temperature and pressure; therefore, the rate of ammonia synthesis is still very low. Researchers have developed a variety of electrochemical cells for room-temperature ammonia synthesis. By changing the temperature and pressure of the reaction, NH3 synthesis can be promoted. The preparation of suitable electrocatalysts and understanding the catalytic mechanism plays a vital role in improving the performance of the NRR. We have summarized four factors including size, electronic, coordination, and orientation effects. These strategies are similar to other electrocatalysis, and their purpose is to increase the number of active sites, regulate the surface electrons, and improve the reactivity and selectivity. Despite the great progress that has been made, there are still challenges in implementing a superior NRR performance under ambient conditions. The reaction overpotential is high, the NH3 yield is low, the Faradaic efficiency is low, and the mechanism of the catalytic process is still unclear. At present, there is still a considerable gap between the electrochemical synthesis of ammonia and actual applications. We believe that several aspects need to be considered: (1) A more in-depth study of the mechanism is required: In theoretical research, the actual reaction conditions, such as the influence of pH, environmental electrolyte, voltage, etc., should be considered, so that the theoretical calculation results match with actual experiments, and the catalytic mechanism can be better explained and understood. (2) Optimization of experimental equipment and conditions: In the case of an aqueous solution, different pH values, electrolytes, and the reaction cell have different effects on the NRR reaction. In an aqueous solution, the competitive HER should be avoided as much as possible. For the installation of an NRR catalytic reaction device, for example, the generation of H2 can be reduced by using an appropriate pressure, and the solubility of N2 can be increased [39]. Increasing the amount of ionic liquid increases reactants dissolution, and can effectively prevent the HER. (3) The rational design of catalysts to avoid the HER: In addition to improvements in the reaction device, the rational design of the catalyst can also achieve this effect. Crystal plane engineering, strain engineering, defect engineering, and special atomic intrinsic properties may all suppress the HER while increasing the NRR. When creating custom built high-selectivity and high-activity NRR catalysts, one should also consider the stability to ensure that the catalyst can still maintains its original characteristics after continuous operation. (4) Advanced characterization techniques for NRR catalysts: The in-situ characterization technology has become increasingly robust in recent years, which provides an auxiliary tool for studying the local electronic structure in catalysts. For example, the method of combining surface-enhanced infrared absorption spectroscopy and electrochemical measurements can be used to study the NRR mechanism of Ru surfaces [155]. These advanced technologies can be used to further understand dynamic reaction processes and reveal the reaction mechanism. In summary, electro-catalytic NRR has made great progress under ambient conditions and has provided many possibilities for future development, but there are still many problems in some areas. We believe we can overcome these problems and make more progress to increase the efficiency of the electrocatalytic synthetic ammonia. coredata.dc:description: The nitrogen cycle plays an important role in nature, but N-containing products cannot meet human needs. The electrochemical synthesis of ammonia under ambient conditions has attracted the interest of many researchers because it provides a clean and pollution-free synthesis method; however, it has certain difficulties, including a high activation energy, multiple electron transfer, and hydrogenation. Thermodynamic factors limit the selectivity and activity of ammonia synthesis techniques. This review summarizes progress in the electrochemical synthesis of ammonia from theory and experiment. Theoretically, the reduction of nitrogen molecules is analyzed using orbit theory and the thermodynamic reaction pathways. Experimentally, we first discuss the effect of the experimental setup on the nitrogen reduction reaction, and then the four critical of catalysts, including size, electronic, coordination, and orientation effects. These issues must be considered to produce highly-efficient catalysts for electrochemical nitrogen reduction (eNRR). This review provides an overview of the eNRR to enable future researchers to design rational catalysts.

coredata.dc:title: Effect on electrochemical reduction of nitrogen to ammonia under ambient conditions: Challenges and opportunities for chemical fuels
